member.name: T:TVA.PhasorProtocols.ConfigurationCellBase
member.summary: Represents the protocol independent common implementation of all configuration elements for cells in a .

member.name: T:TVA.PhasorProtocols.ChannelCellBase
member.summary: Represents the common implementation of the protocol independent representation of any kind of data cell.
member.remarks: This phasor protocol implementation defines a "cell" as a portion of a frame, i.e., a logical unit of data. For example, a (dervied from ) could be defined as a PMU within a frame of data, a , that contains multiple PMU's coming from a PDC.

member.name: T:TVA.PhasorProtocols.ChannelBase
member.summary:
Represents the common implementation of the protocol independent definition of any kind of data that can be parsed or generated.
This is the base class of all parsing/generating classes in the phasor protocols library; it is the root of the parsing/generating class hierarchy.
member.remarks: This base class represents data images for parsing or generation in terms of a header, body and footer (see for details).

member.name: T:TVA.PhasorProtocols.IChannel
member.summary:
Represents a protocol independent interface representation of any data type that can be parsed or generated.
This is the base interface implemented by all parsing/generating classes in the phasor protocols library; it is the root of the parsing/generating interface hierarchy.

member.name: M:TVA.PhasorProtocols.FrameParserBase`1.Flush
member.summary: Clears all buffers for this stream and causes any buffered data to be parsed immediately.

remarks.para: This method is only relevant when is true; otherwise this method has no effect.

If the user has called method, this method will process all remaining buffers on the calling thread until all queued buffers have been parsed - the will then be automatically stopped. This method is typically called on shutdown to make sure any remaining queued buffers get parsed before the class instance is destructed.

It is possible for items to be queued while the flush is executing. The flush will continue to parse buffers as quickly as possible until the internal buffer queue is empty. Unless the user stops queueing data to be parsed (i.e. calling the method), the flush call may never return (not a happy situtation on shutdown).
The does not clear queue prior to destruction. If the user fails to call this method before the class is destructed, there may be data that remains unparsed in the internal buffer.

member.name: M:TVA.PhasorProtocols.FrameParserBase`1.CreateBufferQueue
member.summary: Creates the internal buffer queue.

remarks.para: This method is virtual to allow derived classes to customize the style of processing queue used when consumers choose to implement an internal buffer queue (i.e., set to true). Default type is a real-time queue with the default settings. When overriding this method, be sure to use the method for the ) item processing delegate.

Note that current design only supports synchronous parsing - consumer overriding this method to return an asynchronous (i.e., multi-threaded) process queue will need to redesign the processing delegate.

member.returns: New internal buffer processing queue (i.e., a new ).

member.name: M:TVA.PhasorProtocols.Ieee1344.FrameParser.ParseCommonHeader(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Parses a common header instance that implements for the output type represented in the binary image.
member.param: Offset index into buffer that represents where to start parsing.
Maximum length of valid data from offset.
member.returns: The which includes a type ID for the to be parsed.

remarks.para: Derived classes need to provide a common header instance (i.e., class that implements ) for the output types; this will primarily include an ID of the that the data image represents. This parsing is only for common header information, actual parsing will be handled by output type via its method. This header image should also be used to add needed complex state information about the output type being parsed if needed.

If there is not enough buffer available to parse common header (as determined by ), return null. Also, if the protocol allows frame length to be determined at the time common header is being parsed and there is not enough buffer to parse the entire frame, it will be optimal to prevent further parsing by returning null.

member.name: M:TVA.PhasorProtocols.PhasorValueBase.CalculatePower(TVA.PhasorProtocols.IPhasorValue,TVA.PhasorProtocols.IPhasorValue)
member.summary: Calculates watts from imaginary and real components of a voltage and current phasor.
member.returns: Calculated watts from imaginary and real components of specified and phasors.

member.name: M:TVA.PhasorProtocols.PhasorValueBase.CalculateVars(TVA.PhasorProtocols.IPhasorValue,TVA.PhasorProtocols.IPhasorValue)
member.summary: Calculates vars (total volt-amperes of reactive power) from imaginary and real components of a voltage and current phasor.
member.remarks: Although the units class technically represents watts (i.e., real power) and vars (i.e., imaginary power) are properly expressed in volt-amperes reactive (VAr), the calculated result is still a representation of power and therefore the units class is used to express the return value leaving the consumer to properly apply the needed engineering units for display purposes.
member.returns: Calculated vars (total volt-amperes of reactive power) from imaginary and real components of specified and phasors.

member.name: M:TVA.PhasorProtocols.PhasorValueBase.AverageAngleValueFilter(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{TimeSeriesFramework.IMeasurement})
member.summary: Calculates an average of the specified sequence of phase angle values.
member.param: Sequence of values over which to run calculation.
member.returns: Average of the specified sequence of phase angle values.
member.remarks: Phase angles wrap, so this algorithm takes the wrapping into account when calculating the average.

member.name: M:TVA.PhasorProtocols.IeeeC37_118.FrameParser.ParseCommonHeader(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Parses a common header instance that implements for the output type represented in the binary image.
member.param: Offset index into buffer that represents where to start parsing.
Maximum length of valid data from offset.
member.returns: The which includes a type ID for the to be parsed.

remarks.para: Derived classes need to provide a common header instance (i.e., class that implements ) for the output types; this will primarily include an ID of the that the data image represents. This parsing is only for common header information, actual parsing will be handled by output type via its method. This header image should also be used to add needed complex state information about the output type being parsed if needed.

If there is not enough buffer available to parse common header (as determined by ), return null. Also, if the protocol allows frame length to be determined at the time common header is being parsed and there is not enough buffer to parse the entire frame, it will be optimal to prevent further parsing by returning null.

member.name: T:TVA.PhasorProtocols.IChannelFrame
member.summary: Represents a protocol independent interface representation of any kind of frame of data that contains a collection of objects.

remarks.para: The phasor protocols library defines a "frame" as a collection of cells (logical units of data). For example, a would be defined as a PMU within a frame of data, a (derived from ), that contains multiple PMU's coming from a PDC.
This interface inherits so that classes implementing this interface can be cooperatively integrated into measurement concentration (see ).

member.name: T:TVA.PhasorProtocols.StatisticsReader
member.summary: Reads certain device and input stream statistics from the statistics archive. The statistics that are read are the total frame count, the missing frame count, connectivity, average latency, the actual data rate, data quality errors, and time quality errors.

member.name: M:TVA.PhasorProtocols.StatisticsReader.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the class. All parameters--, , , , , and --must be set manually before attempting to read statistics from the archive.

member.name: M:TVA.PhasorProtocols.StatisticsReader.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the class. The configuration file specified in the parameter must contain the statistics historian records in order to automatically locate the archive files. Otherwise, the other constructor should be used. The and parameters are not set when using this constructor and must be set manually before attempting to read statistics from the archive.
member.param: Path to the openPDC configuration file.

member.name: M:TVA.PhasorProtocols.StatisticsReader.Open
member.summary: Causes the to open the archive file and retrieve the statistics.

member.name: M:TVA.PhasorProtocols.StatisticsReader.Close
member.summary: Closes the archive file once the statistics are no longer needed.

member.name: T:TVA.PhasorProtocols.Macrodyne.ClockStatusFlags
member.summary: Macrodyne clock status flags enumeration (from byte 1 in time string).

member.name: F:TVA.PhasorProtocols.Macrodyne.ClockStatusFlags.DacBeyondLimits
member.summary: Set when DAC811 adjustment on the GPS board is beyond limits.

member.name: F:TVA.PhasorProtocols.Macrodyne.ClockStatusFlags.GpsComIssue
member.summary: Set when the time output is that from the internal buffer (in GPS board processor) incremented by one second.
member.remarks: This implies a problem in communication between the GPS receiver and GPS board.

member.name: F:TVA.PhasorProtocols.Macrodyne.ClockStatusFlags.GpsUnlocked
member.summary: Set when the internal oscillator is not disciplined (the GPS clock is not locked).

member.name: F:TVA.PhasorProtocols.Macrodyne.ClockStatusFlags.GpsTimeInvalid
member.summary: Set when the last GPS receiver time tag was invalid.
member.remarks: The data was received, but flagged as invalid. This may be caused by a loss of satellite visibility.

member.name: F:TVA.PhasorProtocols.Macrodyne.ClockStatusFlags.ResynchronizationPending
member.summary: Set when the system is about to be resynchronized to the GPS receiver.

member.name: F:TVA.PhasorProtocols.Macrodyne.ClockStatusFlags.ErrorCondition
member.summary: Set when an error condition exists.

member.name: F:TVA.PhasorProtocols.Macrodyne.ClockStatusFlags.UsingLocalTime
member.summary: Set for local time mode, cleared for UTC mode.

member.name: F:TVA.PhasorProtocols.Macrodyne.ClockStatusFlags.ClockAndReceiverOutOfSync
member.summary: Set when the GPS clock 1 PPS and the GPS receiver 1 PPS differ by more than 5 microseconds.

member.name: F:TVA.PhasorProtocols.Macrodyne.ClockStatusFlags.NoFlags
member.summary: No flags.

member.name: P:TVA.PhasorProtocols.FNet.ConnectionParameters.TimeOffset
member.summary: Gets or sets time offset of the F-NET device in .
member.remarks: F-NET devices normally report time in 11 seconds past real-time, this property defines the offset for this this artificial delay. Note that the parameter value is in ticks to allow a very high-resolution offset; 1 second = 10,000,000 ticks.

member.summary: Gets or sets flag that determines if the data valid flag assignments should be processed during frame publication.
member.remarks: In cases where client applications ignore the data validity flag, setting this flag to false will provide a slight processing optimization, especially useful on very large data streams.

member.summary: Gets or sets the defined for this .

member.summary: Gets or sets the defined for this .

member.name: P:TVA.PhasorProtocols.PhasorDataConcentratorBase.CurrentScalingValue
member.summary: Gets or sets the integer scaling value to apply to current values published by this .
member.remarks: Typically only the lower 24-bits will be used to scale current values in 10^–5 amperes per bit. Note that this value represents the default value that will be used if user has not specified a value for an individual device.

member.name: P:TVA.PhasorProtocols.PhasorDataConcentratorBase.VoltageScalingValue
member.summary: Gets or sets the integer scaling value to apply to voltage values published by this .
member.remarks: Typically only the lower 24-bits will be used to scale voltage values in 10^–5 volts per bit. Note that this value represents the default value that will be used if user has not specified a value for an individual device.

member.name: P:TVA.PhasorProtocols.PhasorDataConcentratorBase.AnalogScalingValue
member.summary: Gets or sets the integer scaling value to apply to analog values published by this .
member.remarks: Typically only the lower 24-bits will be used to scale analog values in 10^–5 units per bit. Note that this value represents the default value that will be used if user has not specified a value for an individual device.

member.name: P:TVA.PhasorProtocols.PhasorDataConcentratorBase.DigitalMaskValue
member.summary: Gets or sets the digital mask value made available in configuration frames for use with digital values published by this .
member.remarks: This value represents two mask words for use with digital status values. In IEEE C37.118 configuration frames, the two 16-bit words that make up a digital mask value are provided for each defined digital word. Note that this value represents the default value that will be used if user has not specified a value for an individual device. The low word will be used to indicate the normal status of the digital inputs by returning a 0 when exclusive ORed (XOR) with the status word. The high word will indicate the current valid inputs to the PMU by having a bit set in the binary position corresponding to the digital input and all other bits set to 0. If digital status words are used for something other than boolean status indications, the use is left to the user.

member.summary: Start the data parser.

member.name: M:TVA.PhasorProtocols.Macrodyne.FrameParser.ParseCommonHeader(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Parses a common header instance that implements for the output type represented in the binary image.
member.param: Offset index into buffer that represents where to start parsing.
Maximum length of valid data from offset.
member.returns: The which includes a type ID for the to be parsed.

remarks.para: Derived classes need to provide a common header instance (i.e., class that implements ) for the output types; this will primarily include an ID of the that the data image represents. This parsing is only for common header information, actual parsing will be handled by output type via its method. This header image should also be used to add needed complex state information about the output type being parsed if needed.

If there is not enough buffer available to parse common header (as determined by ), return null. Also, if the protocol allows frame length to be determined at the time common header is being parsed and there is not enough buffer to parse the entire frame, it will be optimal to prevent further parsing by returning null.

member.summary: Represents a basic value that is associated with a given .

member.summary: Constructs a new from the specified parameters.

member.summary: Gets the associated with this .

member.name: P:TVA.PhasorProtocols.SignalReferenceMeasurement.IsDiscarded
member.summary: Gets or sets a boolean value that determines if this has been discarded during sorting.
member.remarks: Unlike other properties in the , updates to this property apply to the source reference - updates to other properties will only apply to this instance. Since all measurement operations coming in from the input adapters occur on the same thread (typically the communications thread), the source measurement can be marked as discarded before it hits the archive queue. This way the archived measurement quality flags can be marked to note that the measurement never made it into the real-time processing stream.

member.name: M:TVA.PhasorProtocols.IeeeC37_118.DigitalDefinition.GetLabel(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the individual labels for specified bit in this .
member.param: Index of desired bit label to access.

remarks.para: In the final version of the protocol each digital bit can be labeled, but we read them out as one big string in the "Label" property so this property allows individual access to each label.
Note that the draft 6 implementation of the protocol supports one label for all 16-bits, however draft 7 (i.e., version 1) supports a label for each of the 16 bits.

member.returns: A value of the label corresponding to the parameter.

member.name: M:TVA.PhasorProtocols.IeeeC37_118.DigitalDefinition.SetLabel(System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Sets the individual labels for specified bit in this .
member.param: Index of desired bit label to access.
Value of the bit label to assign.

remarks.para: In the final version of the protocol each digital bit can be labeled, but we read them out as one big string in the "Label" property so this property allows individual access to each label.
Note that the draft 6 implementation of the protocol supports one label for all 16-bits, however draft 7 (i.e., version 1) supports a label for each of the 16 bits.

member.name: P:TVA.PhasorProtocols.FNet.ConfigurationCell.TimeOffset
member.summary: Gets or sets time offset of F-NET device in .
member.remarks: F-NET devices normally report time in 11 seconds past real-time, this property defines the offset for this this artificial delay. Note that the parameter value is in ticks to allow a very high-resolution offset; 1 second = 10,000,000 ticks.

member.name: T:TVA.PhasorProtocols.CommonStatusFlags
member.summary: Protocol independent common status flags enumeration.

remarks.para: These flags are expected to exist in the high-word of a double-word flag set such that original word flags remain in-tact in low-word of double-word flag set.

Note that value being stored in a historian using a 32-bit single precision floating number value will only have castable conversion accuracy back to an unsigned 32-bit integer up to the 24th bit, so any bits used beyond Bit23 will be lossy.

member.name: F:TVA.PhasorProtocols.CommonStatusFlags.DataDiscarded
member.summary: Data was discarded from real-time stream due to late arrival (0 when not discarded, 1 when discarded).

member.name: F:TVA.PhasorProtocols.CommonStatusFlags.DataIsValid
member.summary: Data is valid (0 when device data is valid, 1 when invalid or device is in test mode).

member.name: F:TVA.PhasorProtocols.CommonStatusFlags.SynchronizationIsValid
member.summary: Synchronization is valid (0 when in device is in sync, 1 when it is not).

member.name: F:TVA.PhasorProtocols.CommonStatusFlags.DataSortingType
member.summary: Data sorting type, 0 by timestamp, 1 by arrival.

member.name: F:TVA.PhasorProtocols.CommonStatusFlags.DeviceError
member.summary: Device error (including configuration error), 0 when no error.

member.name: F:TVA.PhasorProtocols.CommonStatusFlags.ReservedFlags
member.summary: Reserved bits for future common flags, presently set to 0.

member.name: F:TVA.PhasorProtocols.CommonStatusFlags.NoFlags
member.summary: No flags.

member.name: T:TVA.PhasorProtocols.SignalKind
member.summary: Fundamental signal types enumeration.

remarks.para: This signal type represents the basic type of a signal used to suffix a formatted signal reference. When used in context along with an optional index the fundamental signal type will identify a signal's location within a frame of data (see ).
Contrast the enumeration with the enumeration which defines an explicit type for a signal (e.g., a voltage or current phasor).

member.name: M:TVA.PhasorProtocols.SelFastMessage.FrameParser.ParseCommonHeader(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Parses a common header instance that implements for the output type represented in the binary image.
member.param: Offset index into buffer that represents where to start parsing.
Maximum length of valid data from offset.
member.returns: The which includes a type ID for the to be parsed.

remarks.para: Derived classes need to provide a common header instance (i.e., class that implements ) for the output types; this will primarily include an ID of the that the data image represents. This parsing is only for common header information, actual parsing will be handled by output type via its method. This header image should also be used to add needed complex state information about the output type being parsed if needed.

If there is not enough buffer available to parse common header (as determined by ), return null. Also, if the protocol allows frame length to be determined at the time common header is being parsed and there is not enough buffer to parse the entire frame, it will be optimal to prevent further parsing by returning null.

member.name: M:TVA.PhasorProtocols.FNet.FrameParser.ParseCommonHeader(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Parses a common header instance that implements for the output type represented in the binary image.
member.param: Offset index into buffer that represents where to start parsing.
Maximum length of valid data from offset.
member.returns: The which includes a type ID for the to be parsed.

remarks.para: Derived classes need to provide a common header instance (i.e., class that implements ) for the output types; this will primarily include an ID of the that the data image represents. This parsing is only for common header information, actual parsing will be handled by output type via its method. This header image should also be used to add needed complex state information about the output type being parsed if needed.

If there is not enough buffer available to parse common header (as determined by ), return null. Also, if the protocol allows frame length to be determined at the time common header is being parsed and there is not enough buffer to parse the entire frame, it will be optimal to prevent further parsing by returning null.

member.name: P:TVA.PhasorProtocols.BpaPdcStream.FrameParser.ParseWordCountFromByte
member.summary: Gets or sets flag that interprets word count in packet header from a byte instead of a word.
member.remarks: Set to true to interpret word count in packet header from a byte instead of a word - if the sync byte (0xAA) is at position one, then the word count would be interpreted from byte four. Some older BPA PDC stream implementations have a 0x01 in byte three where there should be a 0x00 and this throws off the frame length, setting this property to true will correctly interpret the word count.

member.name: T:TVA.PhasorProtocols.MultiProtocolFrameParser
member.summary: Protocol independent frame parser.
member.remarks: This class takes all protocol frame parsing implementations and reduces them to a single simple-to-use class exposing all data through abstract interfaces (e.g., IConfigurationFrame, IDataFrame, etc.) - this way new protocol implementations can be added without adversely affecting consuming code. Additionally, this class implements a variety of transport options (e.g., TCP, UDP, Serial, etc.) and hides the complexities of this connectivity and internally pushes all data received from the selected transport protocol to the selected phasor parsing protocol.

member.summary: Gets or sets flag that determines if a high-resolution precision timer should be used for file based input.
member.remarks:

This is only applicable when connection is made to a file for replay purposes.

member.remarks: When connection is made to a file for replay purposes or consumer doesn't trust remote clock source, this flag can be set to true replace all frame timestamps with a UTC timestamp dervied from the local system clock.
